The best drones you can get for under $200

Just because you're on a budget doesn't mean you can't fly in style.

Tweet

By Dylan Haas2019-04-08 09:00:00 UTC

So, you want to buy a drone, and it turns out you also only have a budget of $200. That’s no problem. The good news is that you have a *ton* of options to choose from — if you simply type “drones under $200” into your Google search bar, you'd find more drones than you can even count. The bad news, however, is that you simply don’t have the time to do all that research, and what’s more is that you can easily buy a piece of crap without even knowing it (and let’s be honest, a lot of them are pieces of crap). 

SEE ALSO: Save $50 on this drone that looks (and flies) like a real bird

Well, we’re here to combat that bad news with some more good news — we did the research for you, and after scouring through countless reviews and drone blogs, we’ve narrowed it down to eight choices that we think are worth taking a look at. This list is a great representation of the various drones you can find across the spectrum (we tried to find a little bit of everything), including features like first-person view, VR capability, one-key functionality, altitude hold, real-time video streaming, educational programs, and more. 

Take the dive with us and educate yourself on the best drones on the market for under $200. When you’re done, we’re confident that you’ll know exactly what you want from your new high-flying friend. 

Longest Flight Time

Image: amazon
The Good
VR-capable • Plastic guards around propellers • Long flight time — bonus battery brings total to 30 minutes • Rubber damper on camera
The Bad
Doesn't handle wind well • No manual take-off option
The Bottom Line
The Altair 818 Hornet is durable and has a decent camera, but the biggest feature is its significantly long flight time.

1. Altair 818 Hornet

The Altair 818 Hornet blends durability with significantly longer flight time than others in its category.
  • Operating Range: 150 meters
  • Charging Time: N/A
  • Flight Time: 15 minutes
  • Weight: 2.9 lbs
$169.8 from Amazon
The Altair 818 Hornet's striking design and color scheme aren't the only great things about it. It comes packed with a good amount of useful features that are hard to find an under-$200 price point. 
First off, this drone is going to last you longer than some of the others on this list. The plastic guards around the Hornet's propellers may add some bulk, but they protect perhaps the most fragile part of the device's body. It's worth it in the long run, especially if you're a newer drone pilot and are expecting to have more than a few accidents. The included 720p camera has a rubber damper, so you don't have to worry about it producing shaky footage. The drone's first person view is accessible from either the companion mobile app or a VR headset. The big selling point for the Altair 818, though, is its battery life. For its price, this drone has one of the longest flight times we've seen, clocking in at 15 minutes per battery (most max out at 7-10 minutes). As an added bonus, Altair includes a second battery — that's 30 minutes of flying, right out of the box.
If you plan on spending as much time as possible with your drone, the Altair 818 Hornet is a great choice.

Most Well-Rounded

Image: Amazon
The Good
Lots of great features from across the drone spectrum • Real-time transmission
The Bad
Jack of all trades, but a master of none
The Bottom Line
The DROCON U818 is a well-rounded drone that is perfect for someone looking for a little bit of everything.

2. DROCON U818

The DROCON U818 is a well-rounded drone that is perfect if you're looking for a lot of features.
  • Operating Range: 150 meters
  • Charging Time: 180 minutes
  • Flight Time: 10-15 minutes
  • Weight: 2.8 lbs
$149.99 from Amazon
There isn't just one feature to focus on when it comes to the DROCON U818 — it's got a little bit of everything. 
No matter which of this drone's functions you put under the spotlight, you'll find something worthwhile. The footage quality and operational range both deliver high-quality results. It has a good FPV view, streams video in real-time, and it's super easy to learn with. The DROCON U818 takes a little bit from some of the best budget drones, and combines them into one machine. What more is there to say?
Check out Amazon user McKay C's review of the DROCON U818:
I have flown a lot of drones in this price range and I must say out of all of them, this one has the most stable altitude hold and control. In conjunction with that, the video is also very stable (I think it has some sort of anti-shake feature). Not only that, but the camera image quality is actually quite decent. It is only 720p instead of 1080p but it still has better quality than I have seen on other drones similar to this.
I think because of how easy this is to control and because of how well the altitude hold works on this, this makes for a really nice beginner drone package. It is a great way to learn how to fly a drone. Another advantage to this drone is that because it is so lightweight, it gets really good fly time and is very resistant to damage. I guess on the flip side of that, it does not perform incredibly well in the wind.
I really like the design and feel of the remote control and it has really good range. Overall, I really like this drone and have had a lot of fun flying it. I think it is a good drone for younger kids too.




Best Learning Drone

Image: DJI
The Good
Helps you learn coding basics • Program multiple drones at once • Mission pads with unique IDs
The Bad
More range would be beneficial for advanced coding
The Bottom Line
The Tello EDU is a great way to learn how to code and see your work play out immediately in front of you.

3. Tello EDU

The Tello EDU is a great way to learn how to code and see your work play out immediately in front of you.
  • Operating Range: 100 meters
  • Charging Time: 90 minutes
  • Flight Time: 13 minutes
  • Weight: 0.2 lbs
$129 from DJI
The Tello EDU is a very special drone. This thing isn't just a toy, it's an educational device that can help you learn the extremely beneficial skill of coding.
Within the Tello's accompanying mobile app, you can simply drag blocks of code onto the screen and command your drone to pull off flips, fly to specific points, and more. Once you become familiar with the coding blocks, users are welcome to start typing out code themselves and customizing their drone's AI. The Tello even comes with an engaging space travel game that teaches you coding basics on an adventure through the cosmos. The package also comes with four separate "mission pads" — all of which have a unique ID that the Tello can recognize and can serve as command points in your code. The EDU also features a "drone swarm" ability that enables users to code for multiple Tello drones at once and perform an aerial acrobatics show. With 13 minutes of flight time, there's a lot you can do (and it charges easily via USB). 
The Tello EDU is a must-have for those who want to learn how to code and see immediate results — all while having a great time doing it. 

Most Affordable

Image: amazon
The Good
On the cheap side • Good for practicing • Durable
The Bad
Lower-end features • Video is a bit grainy
The Bottom Line
The UDI U818A sacrifices some features, but you just can't beat that low price.

4. UDI U818A

The UDI U818A sacrifices some features, but you just can't beat that low price.
  • Operating Range: 80-100 meters
  • Charging Time: 120 minutes
  • Flight Time: 6-9 minutes
  • Weight: 0.9 lbs
$54.99 from Amazon
While you may be sacrificing some features by going with this drone, there is one thing you won't be sacrificing — your hard-earned cash. Hitting below the $100 mark, this super low-budget drone holds up pretty well against the others on our list. 
Complete with a headless mode to cut out any steep learning curves, six-axis flight control, 3D rolling capability, and a decent HD video camera — it comes chock-full of features for a fraction of the price. The other drones on the list have higher-quality versions of all of these things, but what they don't have is the price. If you need something on the cheap that you just want to learn and practice with, give the UDI U818A a try.
Amazon user Freund had a positive experience with the UDI U818A:
This quad-copter is very affordable and durable. I've crashed it into trees, the ground, and even my house and it still works well. I found I have much better control on speed level 2, especially in the wind.
The video is grainy and the motors are fairly loud in video, but for the price I can't complain. I have attached a picture taken from the UDI camera in flight as an example of the quality.








Most Popular

Image: amazon
The Good
Well-rounded • 3D flips • Altitude Hold
The Bad
One-key return not always reliable • Weak against high wind speeds
The Bottom Line
The Holy Stone F181W is the most reviewed drone on Amazon at this price point — and for good reason.

5. Holy Stone F181W

The Holy Stone F181W is the most reviewed drone on Amazon at this price point — and for good reason.
  • Operating Range: 50-100 meters
  • Charging Time: 70-90 minutes
  • Flight Time: 7-10 minutes
  • Weight: 0.3 lbs
$119.95 from Amazon
The Holy Stone F181W is the most consistently reviewed drone at this price point on Amazon right now (almost reaching 2,000 reviews total, 72% of them being five stars) — I guess you could say the Holy Stone is the "cool kid" in school. Truth is, it's reviewed often because it's a great drone with great features.
The F181W is comparable to the DROCON U818 in that it's extremely well-rounded in terms of the full package. The only difference is that the Holy Stone has a few more advanced features that probably better suit experienced flyers. Some of these extra features include one-key 3D flips, a controllable LED light, and an awesome altitude hold function. It's also pretty decent in regard to operational range and flight time — on par with most other drones on the market at this price. 
Amazon user Bob T. says:
This drone is exceptionally stable in flight. It is the most stable drone I have that doesn't have GPS or optical hold. Of course, it is at the mercy of wind or air currents, but it holds its altitude exceptionally well. The low rpm props make it very quiet. It is less than 250 grams, so it is not governed by any U.S. FAA rules. I have only two complaints about this drone are that it automatically lands or descends to about 30 feet when it loses control signal or has low battery, respectively. They are software problems which are easily fixed. The customer support for Holy Stone drones is the best I've ever encountered. If you visit the HolyStone.com site, you will get a pop-up support window, and my experience is that there is always someone there who is willing and able to help you. There is also a phone number, but I haven't tried that yet. I had a out-of-range fly-away with my first F181 and Holy Stone sent me a new one in less than a week. I could not have asked for more.

Best Flight Modes

Image: Amazon
The Good
Long flight time • Custom flight patterns • One-key take-off and landing
The Bad
Doesn't have great range • Custom flight patterns sometimes inconsistent
The Bottom Line
The Altair AA108 is best for those who want an uncomplicated drone with multiple skill levels and simple controls.

6. Altair AA108

The Altair AA108 is best for those who want an uncomplicated drone with multiple skill levels and simple controls.
  • Operating Range: 100 meters
  • Charging Time: N/A
  • Flight Time: 10 minutes
  • Weight: 1.7 lbs
$129.8 from Amazon
Another great product from Altair, the AA108 also boasts some noteworthy features.
The AA108 includes three different flying modes that match the user's skills: Beginner, mid-level, and advanced. Like the Altair's 818 Hornet, this drone has a pretty long-lasting flight time — about 10 minutes per battery. With the set's included extra battery, that's 20 minutes of just you and your new flying toy. The AA108 also packs a camera that gets pretty superb-looking footage considering the low price you're paying, and its low-battery and out-of-range alarms are very helpful in what would usually be a stressful situation. Probably the neatest feature here is the device's custom flight patterns feature, in which you can physically draw out a path that the AA108 will subsequently follow. The one-button landing and take-off functions are also really useful for the more advanced parts of flight. Altair is said to be known for its supportive customer service, as well.
Amazon user Lancer X had this to say about the Altair AA108:
My family just returned from the park after another fun afternoon of flying drones around expansive lawn. I’ve been very impressed with this little Altair drone - both with the model itself and with the great customer service from the US company behind it. I have had several contacts with the support team (*not* quality issues), and they were always patient and accommodating.
The drone is really stable and quite easy to fly, so seems like a great choice for a beginner like me. It also seems to be quite durable. We haven’t had any bad crashes, but plenty of mild bumps. I haven’t accurately timed the flight duration, but the AA108 seems to exceed the listed claims, even in wind and when I’m really pushing it hard.
I’m really satisfied with my choice, and love this little drone that I order another for the kids. I would recommend picking up a couple of extra batteries - you will want the fun to last!
I don’t have any major complaints, but by way of feedback, the port for the micro SD card is a little fiddly - not exactly easy to get the card in and out. The charging cable for the batteries could be a few inches longer too.
If you’re looking for your first drone, I would recommend going with this model over some of the $40-60 USD choices. We have a Holy Stone Predator, and while it is still very fun to fly, this drone is simply more forgiving and also better-performing.


Best FPV/VR Capability

Image: amazon
The Good
Great FPV and VR modes • Easy to fly
The Bad
Poor wind performance
The Bottom Line
The Force 1 U45W Blue Jay is made for VR enthusiasts who want to be immersed and always directly involved in the action.

7. Force 1 U45W Blue Jay

The Force 1 U45W Blue Jay is made for VR enthusiasts who want to be immersed and always directly involved in the action.
  • Operating Range: 100 meters
  • Charging Time: 60 minutes
  • Flight Time: 7-8 minutes
  • Weight: 0.3 lbs
$129.99 from Amazon
The Force 1 U45W Blue Jay is a decent drone in terms of flight performance, but where it really shines is its first-person and virtual reality functions. 
Streamed in real-time right to your mobile phone, you can get a great view of exactly what the Blue Jay is seeing. If you're looking to get an even more immersive experience, you can sync up your VR headset with the drone — making it feel like you're literally in the pilot's seat. In every other department, it hits the average marks of most drones under the $200 dollar mark. It has a nice 720p HD camera, a helpful headless mode to keep things simple, and a stable altitude hold function for when you want the drone to stay in its current position. It also includes one-key landing and take-off, as well as a custom route mode. 
Check out the Force 1 U45W Blue Jay if you want to really put yourself into your drone's shoes for a change.  

Furthest Operating Range

Image: B&H Photo Video
The Good
Far operational range • Multiple speed settings • Durable • Comes with an extra set of blades
The Bad
Long charge time • Heavy
The Bottom Line
The Polaroid PL2900 Quadcopter can travel further than any other drone we've seen at this price.

8. Polaroid PL2900 Quadcopter

The Polaroid PL2900 Quadcopter can travel further than any other drone we've seen at this price.
  • Operating Range: 300 meters
  • Charge Time: 250 minutes
  • Flight Time: 10 minutes
  • Weight: 5 lbs
$189 from B&H Photo Video
Finally, a brand name you probably recognize. The Polaroid PL2900 is a beautiful drone that prides itself on the distance it can travel. While most drones at this price usually max out at around 100 meters, the Polaroid triples that. 
A lot of the usual suspects are also here — headless mode, one-key auto landing function, and altitude hold among them. The included camera is very high-quality (it *is* Polaroid, after all) and you can stream real-time footage from up to 200 meters away (with an extra 100 meters of non real-time flight). The drone's three different flight modes also give some room for dipping your feet in slowly if you're new to flying, and the bundle includes an extra set of blades in case you suffer a nasty crash. The main downside to the PL2900 is that it takes a pretty long time to charge, but considering its ability to travel so far, it may just be worth the wait.
